title: Bringing Animations to Life: Interactive dotLottie with JavaScript üöÄ

dateTime.displayText: Tuesday, March 25, 20256:00 PM to 9:00 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

In this hands-on free workshop, we‚Äôll explore the power of dotLottie, the lightweight, flexible animation format that enhances web performance and interactivity. You'll learn how to integrate dotLottie animations seamlessly into your JavaScript projects and take them beyond static visuals by adding real-time user interactions using event-driven techniques.

By the end of this workshop, you‚Äôll be able to:

  • Load and control dotLottie animations dynamically in JavaScript
  • Trigger animations based on user inputs (scroll, hover, clicks, and more)
  • Optimize animations for smooth performance and responsiveness
  • Use dotLottie in real-world applications (websites, apps, UI elements)

Whether you're a developer, designer, or UI/UX enthusiast, this session will equip you with practical skills to elevate your animations and create engaging web experiences with ease.

Meet Our Speaker‚ú®

Karin Fam - Tech Lead at LottieFiles
Curious software engineer looking to change the world, one "Hello, world!" at a time. Currently passionate about making pixels move themselves.

title: ‚ÄùDoing ‚Äúthe right thing‚Äù: existential quandaries in software development"

dateTime.displayText: Friday, December 6, 20248:30 AM to 9:30 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

üôå TorontoJS Tech Talks [ Online ] is back again!
We're thrilled to announce the return of TorontoJS Tech Talks to the virtual stage!
The practice of building software every day involves making decisions, large and small. Every bug, incident, and feature raises questions of how to best solution for speed to market while maintaining quality and security. Besides banging out code, the work of software building requires getting buy-in on the approach and presenting risks or tradeoffs that can be uncomfortable and controversial.
In this talk, Jen Chan recounts challenges and learnings from trying (and sometimes failing) to do ‚Äúthe right thing‚Äù on highly ambitious and challenging software projects.
Bio:Jen Chan is a software developer who spent the last 8 years barreling through 3 startups, 2 agencies, 1 well-known public company. She lives in Toronto with a cat.

üëã Meet Our Special Guest,
Jen Chan

Schedule:
6:30 pm- Warm welcome and introduction by TorontoJS
6:40 pm - Presentation by our esteemed speaker.
7:30 m - Interactive Q&A Session
7:45 PM - Closing Remarks

This event will unfold on Zoom, bringing together minds from everywhere in an inspiring virtual space.

title: Accessibility for Devs Series: Online Talks and panel Q&A

dateTime.displayText: Tuesday, November 19, 20248:00 AM to 11:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

This is our fourth Accessibility for Devs event and the second in-person one! Topic and location are TBA but register early as these events will fill up fast.

This event will have 2 or 3 talks each geared to a different levels of dev skills/career stage followed by some networking time and a panel Q&A.

  • Would you like to advance your career and improve your software development skills with accessibility in mind?
  • Are you curious about accessibility ("a11y") but don't know where to start?
  • Have you attended other web accessibility events, but they seem to be geared more to designers and product managers?
  • Do you know that accessibility is becoming increasingly important for legal, business, and human rights reasons?

Well then this is the series for you!

The Accessibility for Devs Talk & Workshop Series is designed for developers and run by developers. Every event will have a live coding demo and/or hands on practice so you can level up your skills.

About Accessibility for Devs Talk & Workshop Series:

  • On the third Monday of every month
  • Alternating between online and in-person events
  • Open to all skill levels
  • Coding focus but no accessibility knowledge required
  • Run by the new Accessibility Team at TorontoJS!

Accessibility of Accessibility for Devs Talk & Workshop Series:
(Because accessibility isn't just about users!)

  • All in-person events will be wheelchair accessible and have easy access to an accessible subway station or streetcar route.
  • Online events will have auto captioning enabled and presenters/hosts will do our best to provide described audio of visuals.
  • Talks uploaded to YouTube will have both captions and transcripts (Please note: It may take a while for the first few YouTube videos to have captions and transcripts as we are setting up the new accessibility team. We're looking for volunteers!)

***
About TorontoJS: ‚ÑπÔ∏è
Did you know that our members and volunteers are not just in Toronto, and that we're not just JavaScript! We welcome people from any field in tech and with any level of skills - from students and those considering a career change up to seasoned professionals with decades of experience.
TorontoJS is dedicated to providing a welcoming, safe, inclusive and supportive environment for all regardless of their gender, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, or religion.
Please read the code of conduct prior to attending this meeting. https://torontojs.com/code_of_conduct
We welcome and encourage people who are disabled, neurodivergent, deaf/Deaf, LGBTQ2S+, and BIPOC, to attend events, get involved as members and to volunteer!
***
Connect With TorontoJS üîó

  • Website: https://torontojs.com
  • Join us on Slack!
  • Follow us on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/torontojs/
  • You can also find TorontoJS events on Guild.host: https://guild.host/torontojs/events

***

title: Code Club Online: Nightmare Before React

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, October 27, 20245:00 AM to 7:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

About Code Club
TorontoJS Code Club is a friendly coding environment where we can bounce ideas & ask questions freely while working on software challenges together.
Please bring your projects/ideas to the event, or just show up and contribute to the discussion!

  • We can tackle an open-source issue together. Some issues don't require much context to solve and are suitable for beginners too. This group programming event can be a great opportunity to start your open-source journey.
  • We can hack on personal projects together. Is there a bug in your software that you want to fix with the group? Is there a feature you want to add? How about some refactoring to clean up your codebase? It's fun to see how everyone has different approaches to solve these technical challenges.
  • Are you job searching? We can take a look at Leetcode-style interview questions together.
  • Countless new libraries appear in the JS ecosystem every year. We can try out a new piece of tech together and share our first impressions.

This event is not about competition or achievements. Come for the pure joy of building. Everyone is welcome!

Platform
The event will be hosted on the TorontoJS discord server, on the #js-code-club channel.

Accessibility Accommodations
This is an online event on Discord, please feel free to contact us at [events@torontojs.com](mailto:events@torontojs.com) if you need any accommodations for the event.
Our Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events.

Image description
A pumpkin patch from The Nightmare Before Christmas with a full moon on the center of the image, in front of the full moon there is the CN Tower showing. Overlaid on the image it reads: Toronto JS - Code Club - October 2024

title: UXUI Design Online Talk: Design Systems - A Survival Guide

dateTime.displayText: Thursday, October 3, 20247:00 AM to 9:45 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

This is our first UIUX Design event run by the new TorontoJS design team!

  • Would you like to advance your career and improve your UIUX Design and Frontend skills?
  • Are you a graphic designer who wants to improve your UI design skills?
  • Are you a frontend developer that wants to improve your design and Figma skills?
  • Would you like to be part of a tech meetup community where developers listen to and value designers?

Well then this is the series for you!
The UIUX Design Series is designed for designers and frontend developers and run by the TorontoJS Design Team.
Location: Online
Topic: Design Systems
Agenda
1 - What is NOT a Design System?
‚ÄúFalse Tracks: Misleading Signs in the Wild‚Äù
Focus on common misconceptions and what design systems are not.
2 - What is a Design System?
‚ÄúDefining the Species: Identifying a True Design System‚Äù
Explore the fundamental characteristics of a design system.
3-Design Systems as Product
‚ÄúThe Ecosystem: Living and Breathing as a Product‚Äù
Discuss viewing the design system as a product with its own lifecycle.
4 - Challenges: Survival in the Wilderness

  • Concept: Planting the Seeds
  • ‚Å†Raise: Nurturing Growth
  • ‚Å†Adopt: Finding Allies and Surviving
  • Scale: Thriving or Failing to Adapt

5-Wrap Up
‚ÄúSurvival Lessons: What We‚Äôve Learned from the Wild‚Äù
Recap the key takeaways that help design systems endure.
6-Q&A
‚ÄúCampfire Stories: Sharing
Speaker: Victor Montalv√£o
Victor Montalvao is a seasoned design leader with over 15 years of experience shaping digital products and user experiences. As Senior Group Design Manager at SmartRecruiters, Victor led the design discipline across the Platform groups, as well as the Design System and Accessibility Program. With experience at companies such as Philips, Globo, Oi and Xello, he combines strategic vision with practical experience. Victor is passionate about transforming complex challenges into intuitive solutions and driving innovation through design.

Accessibility of UIUX Design Talk & Workshop Series:
(Because accessibility isn't just about users!)

  • All in-person events will be wheelchair accessible and have easy access to an accessible subway station or streetcar route.
  • Online events will have auto captioning enabled and presenters/hosts will do our best to provide described audio of visuals.
  • Talks uploaded to YouTube will have both captions and transcripts (Please note: It may take a while for the first few YouTube videos to have captions and transcripts as we are setting up the new accessibility team. We're looking for volunteers!)

***
About TorontoJS: ‚ÑπÔ∏è
Did you know that our members and volunteers are not just in Toronto, and that we're not just JavaScript! We welcome people from any field in tech and with any level of skills - from students and those considering a career change up to seasoned professionals with decades of experience.
TorontoJS is dedicated to providing a welcoming, safe, inclusive and supportive environment for all regardless of their gender, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, or religion.
Please read the code of conduct prior to attending this meeting. We welcome and encourage people who are disabled, neurodivergent, deaf/Deaf, LGBTQ2S+, and BIPOC, to attend events, get involved as members and to volunteer!

title: JS Tech Talk [In Person] - September 2024

dateTime.displayText: Wednesday, September 25, 20246:00 PM to 9:00 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

Welcome back folks, to another exciting Tech Talk event at Super.com on September 25!

Join us for some drinks, snacks, and Tech Talks.

Make sure to mark your calendars and come out and join us for this event as we say hello to Fall!

Agenda

"From RUM to Front-End Observability with OpenTelemetry"
In this talk, we‚Äôll dive into how to use tracing with OpenTelemetry to start surfacing unknown-unknowns, whether you‚Äôre using React, Angular or {insert-frontend-framework-of-the-month}.
by Purvi Kanal

Zalgo and other eldritch unicode horrors

Let's talk about string encoding, accented characters, and how to deal with Unicode
by Marco Campos

Schedule:
6:00pm - doors open
6:30pm to 7:00pm - From RUM to Front-End Observability with OpenTelemetry by Purvi Kanal
7:00pm to 7:30pm - Zalgo and Other Eldritch Unicode Horrors by Marco Campos
7:30pm to 9:00pm - Networking
9:00pm - doors close
(Note: All times in the schedule are an approximation.)

Please RSVP to confirm your attendance. If you have your friends or teammates joining please ask them to RSVP as well.

You can also RSVP at Guild if Meetup is full!
https://guild.host/events/js-tech-talk-in-person-ixwtxw

This event is open to all skill levels.

Many thanks to [Super.com](https://super.com) for hosting us and Sanity for supporting us!

We're looking for sponsors for events like these. If you or your company would like to support TorontoJS and get a message out to our community, please get in touch with [organizers@torontojs.com](mailto:organizers@torontojs.com)

The Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events and spaces - online or in-person.

TorontoJS is a volunteer-led not-for-profit organization. Please help us with tidying up. otherwise, the venue staff and volunteers will have to pick up after you.

detailsHtml:
Details

This is our second Accessibility for Devs event and the first in-person one! Topic and location are TBA but register early as these events will fill up fast.

  • Would you like to advance your career and improve your software development skills with accessibility in mind?
  • Are you curious about accessibility ("a11y") but don't know where to start?
  • Have you attended other web accessibility events, but they seem to be geared more to designers and product managers?
  • Do you know that accessibility is becoming increasingly important for legal, business, and human rights reasons?

Well then this is the series for you!

The Accessibility for Devs Talk & Workshop Series is designed for developers and run by developers. Every event will have a live coding demo and/or hands on practice so you can level up your skills.

Location: Online
Topic: Using Refreshable Braille Display and NVDA Screen Reader for Web Development and CyberSecurity
Speaker: Florian Beijers

About Accessibility for Devs Talk & Workshop Series:

title: TorontoJS PubScript Social at The Firkin on Yonge!

dateTime.displayText: Friday, September 6, 20246:30 PM to 10:30 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

We're BACK! Your favourite TorontoJS social event at at pub is being resurrected after the pandemic. And the best part is, it will more inclusive and wheelchair accessible this time.

Friends + Code + Pub = FUN!

TorontoJS PubScript event is a fun relaxed event where like-minded individuals get together, have a snack, meal, or drink, network, and talk software development and tech.

  • Ping-pong/table tennis table and dart boards will be available.
  • Everyone is welcome to join us. If you are coming for the first time, don't be shy!
  • This is a relaxed social event. It's totally fine if you need to arrive late or leave early.
  • Current, past, and new members welcome, both drinkers and non-drinkers!

Attendees can also register on TorontoJS's page on Guild: https://guild.host/torontojs/events

Location
The Firkin on Yonge is on the east side of Yonge Street, just north of Queen Street and across from the Eaton Centre.
Firkin on Yonge
207 Yonge St
Toronto, Ontario
M5B 2H1
Google Maps link

Menu
View the menu online.
Traditional English and North American pub food is available, as are alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks options.

Notes:

  • The TorontoJS Code of Conduct applies. Be nice! Read the code of conduct online.
  • Please make sure to be respectful to staff and tip well!
  • The Firkin isn't charging TorontoJS a booking fee for the PubScript series of socials or other social events.
  • We're thrilled to have a free venue for regular social events and want to keep a positive relationship with the Firkin!
  • We have members, volunteers, and future guests who use mobility aids (walking canes, wheelchairs, and service dogs) - including ones organizing our social events.
  • Under no circumstances should anyone ever touch a mobility aid (e.g. mobility cane, crutches, or wheelchair) or distract a service dog! Treat mobility aids as extensions of a person - even when the person isn't currently using their mobility aid. If you need a mobility aid moved, ask the person it belongs to.

### Transit:

  • TTC: Right near Queen TTC Station, and on the Yonge bus line
  • GO Transit: Two stops north of Union Station on the Yonge subway line

### Cycling:

  • Close to the Richmond and Adelaide east/west cycle tracks
  • There's Bike Share Toronto docking stations nearby. The closest is on Richmond Street at Yonge.

### Driving:

  • Check with Green P for public parking lots. With the Firkin on Yonge being in the heart of downtown Toronto there's parking, but it's much easier to take transit.

## Accessibility Notes:

### Venue

The Firkin is wheelchair accessible with level access, elevator to the second floor and to the washrooms in the basement. Washrooms are accessible with accessible stalls in each gendered washroom. The Firkin hosts events by A11yTO, so the staff handles disability accommodation requests professionally and respectfully.

### Transit

The closest accessible station is usually Queen Station, but due to water damage the northbound platform station is not accessible until July, 2024. If you are arriving from Union or if you are going home north bound you will need an alternate route.

The closest accessible TTC routes are:

  1. Yonge bus north to Dundas Station or Wellesley Station
  2. St. Andrew Station, then the King Street streetcar east to Yonge Street. Walk or roll north three blocks. The streetcar tracks on the east side of Queen are filled in so it's an easy wheel over them (no front casters getting stuck)!
  3. Union, then the Bay bus north. Catch the bus at the SE corner of Bay and Front Streets. Get off at Queen and Bay. Walk or roll east one block. (Note there is construction so it's quite a tight sidewalk with bumps.)

WheelTrans can drop off on Yonge. The Firkin entrance is right near the stairway TTC entrance on the sidewalk.

If you need accessibility accommodations, please reply to this form: https://forms.gle/FqQf6w8csEJjehiF7

***Please contact the organizers if you have any accessibility questions or concerns.***

title: TorontoJS [ ONLINE ] TechTalk: Arhitecture For Small Projects / Form Validation

dateTime.displayText: Friday, August 30, 20247:00 AM to 9:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

TorontoJS Tech Talks [ Online ] is back again!

We're thrilled to announce the return of TorontoJS Tech Talks to the virtual stage! In this session, we're diving into the topic of choosing architecture for small projects and form validation with almost no JavaScript!

Meet Our Special Guest,

Evert Pot CTO @ Sprout and Marco Campos Senior Developer @ Lights On Software.

Evert has been a software engineer for 20 years. During this time he's been a part of several startups, with mixed outcomes! Evert is a fan of APIs and open standards and maintains several open-source projects.

Marco is a software developer with 15 years of experience, during that time he worked with both backend and frontend using different technologies. Marco is a fan of the open and standard web, and chooses to build things as vanilla as possible

Schedule:

title: New Volunteer Information and Orientation Online Meeting!

dateTime.displayText: Wednesday, August 21, 20247:30 AM to 8:20 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

Do you want to be part of an awesome community that's one of the largest tech meetups in the world, while gaining career experience, building a portfolio, and developing your leadership skills and professional portfolio?

TorontoJS is recruiting volunteers for in-person, hybrid, and remote positions!

Did you know that our members and volunteers are not just in Toronto, and that we're not just JavaScript! We welcome people from any field in tech and with any level of skills - from students and those considering a career change up to seasoned professionals with decades of experience.

TorontoJS is dedicated to providing a welcoming, safe, inclusive and supportive environment for all regardless of their gender, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, or religion.
Please read the code of conduct prior to attending this meeting. https://torontojs.com/code_of_conduct

We're growing!
There's four new teams with a wide range of programs and various levels of volunteer roles:

  1. Volunteer Management Team
  2. Accessibility Team
  3. Design Team
  4. Women in Tech

We also need events volunteers for both in-person and online events.

Commitment for roles ranges from one evening a month and/or half an hour a week, through to leadership positions with long-term commitments.
All volunteers will be invited to attend volunteer only special events including the new "May the Fourth annual volunteer party"!

This is a meeting for new and existing volunteers interested in positions for:

  • The new Design Team,
  • Volunteer management team,
  • Accessibility team, and
  • Women in Tech team (leadership)
  • In-person and online Events,

This meeting will cover:

  • History and info about TorontoJS
  • About how TorontoJS is growing.
  • The new Volunteer Management Software (VMS) development project.
  • Current and future volunteer positions
  • Timelines
  • Expectations
  • Volunteer benefits
  • how these positions will help TorontoJS members and volunteers
  • Q&A

title: A11y for Devs: BlindlyCoding - How I use a Screenreader to Code as a Blind Dev

dateTime.displayText: Tuesday, August 20, 20247:00 AM to 8:45 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

The first event of the new monthly Accessibility for Devs Talk & Workshop Series! ü•≥

  • Have you ever wondered how blind and low vision developers write code?
  • Are you curious about screen readers but don't know where to start?

In this online talk, demo, and Q&A Florian Beijers will show how he uses the NVDA screenreader to write code both for work and while streaming.
Schedule:

  • TBA

About Accessibility for Devs Talk & Workshop Series:

  • Third Monday of every month
  • Alternating between online and in-person events
  • Open to all skill levels
  • Coding focus but no accessibility knowledge required
  • Run by the new Accessibility Team at TorontoJS!
  • *All in-person events will be wheelchair accessible
  • *Online events will have auto captioning enabled and presenters/hosts will do our best to provide described audio of visuals.
  • Talks uploaded to YouTube will have both captions and transcripts (Please note: It may take a while for the first few YouTube videos to have captions and transcripts as we are setting up the new accessibility team. We're looking for volunteers!)

Meet Florian Beijers: üëã
"Throughout my day, I wear quite a few hats. Professionally speaking I'm a developer. A coder, programmer, webdev, super awesome rockstar ninja guru extreme. I also dabble in sarcasm.

I have worked, and will work, on a variety of different projects in different spaces, including web app backends, mobile applications and the occasional project using JS frameworks like React and Vue.

I have also worked as a lead coder for a text-based game for just over a year, something that allowed me to dip my toes into game development.

Alongside, and tangentially related to, my development work, I am an accessibility consultant.

I also simultaneously stream on Twitch and YouTube several times a week
Gaming: https://www.twitch.tv/Zersaix
Coding (IC_null): https://www.twitch.tv/ic_null
YouTube (BlindlyCoding): @blindlycoding
https://florianbeijers.xyz
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/florianbeijers/

title: Code Club: August Edition

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, August 18, 20245:00 AM to 7:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

No bad puns with the title this time, but we still hope to work in nice and cool projects!

So, bring yours or just join us for a fun time!

About Code Club
TorontoJS Code Club is a friendly coding environment where we can bounce ideas & ask questions freely while working on software challenges together.

Please bring your projects/ideas to the event, or just show up and contribute to the discussion!

  • We can tackle an open-source issue together. Some issues don't require much context to solve and are suitable for beginners too. This group programming event can be a great opportunity to start your open-source journey.

  • We can hack on personal projects together. Is there a bug in your software that you want to fix with the group? Is there a feature you want to add? How about some refactoring to clean up your codebase? It's fun to see how everyone has different approaches to solve these technical challenges.

  • Are you job searching? We can take a look at Leetcode-style interview questions together.

  • Countless new libraries appear in the JS ecosystem every year. We can try out a new piece of tech together and share our first impressions.

This event is not about competition or achievements. Come for the pure joy of building. Everyone is welcome!

Platform
The event will be hosted on the TorontoJS discord server, on the #js-code-club channel.

Accessibility Accommodations
This is an online event on Discord, please feel free to contact us at [events@torontojs.com](mailto:events@torontojs.com) if you need any accommodations for the event.

Our Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events.

title: Women in Tech Online Social and New Volunteer Info Session

dateTime.displayText: Wednesday, August 14, 20247:30 AM to 8:20 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

TorontoJS is starting a new, permanent Women in Tech program and series of events! If you're looking to become a part of and grow an in-person and online community of professional women in tech this is your chance!

This online event is both an online social and an information session for new members and those interested in volunteering for in-person and/or virtual positions.

We welcome and encourage people who are disabled, neurodivergent, deaf/Deaf, LGBTQ2S+, and BIPOC, to attend events, get involved as members and to volunteer!

This event is open to women, binary and non-gender people, and trans-women.

Commitment for roles ranges from one evening a month and/or half an hour a week, through to leadership positions with long-term commitments.

All volunteers will be invited to attend volunteer only special events including the new "May the Fourth annual volunteer party"!

Did you know that our members and volunteers are not just in Toronto, and that we're not just JavaScript! We welcome people from any field in tech and with any level of skills - from students and those considering a career change up to seasoned professionals with decades of experience.

TorontoJS is dedicated to providing a welcoming, safe, inclusive and supportive environment for all regardless of their gender, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, or religion.

Please read the code of conduct prior to attending this meeting. https://torontojs.com/code_of_conduct

We also have a Women in Tech Picnic on Sunday, August 11th near Davisville station.

** Men/males, if you're looking to volunteer please register for an upcoming volunteer information session and/or join our Slack and post a comment in the general channel.

title: Women in Tech Summer Picnic in the Park!

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, August 11, 20242:30 PM to 6:30 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

TorontoJS is starting a new, permanent Women in Tech program and series of events!
Come out to Oriel Park beside Davisville TTC Station for a fun, relaxed social picnic in the park!

Everyone in tech or considering a career change is welcome. Please feel free to bring a guest or two.

If you're a crafter please feel free to bring a project. The host will be bringing her knitting (it's binary code after all ;-) )

More details (including the snacks/dessert menu) coming soon.

***

TorontoJS is a safe space.
The code of conduct applies to this event and all other ones.
We welcome and encourage people who are disabled, neurodivergent, deaf/Deaf, LGBTQ2S+, and BIPOC, to attend events, get involved as members and to volunteer!

This event is open to women, binary and non-gender people, and trans-women.

Under no circumstances should anyone ever touch a mobility aid (e.g. mobility cane, crutches, or wheelchair) or distract a service dog!
Treat mobility aids as extensions of a person - even when the person isn't currently using their mobility aid. If you need a mobility aid moved, ask the person it belongs to.

Transportation

  • Transit: 2-5 minute walk from Davisville TTC station
  • Cycling: On multiple bike routes with a Toronto Bike Share station in the park
  • WheelTrans: ask to be dropped off at 25 Frobisher Ave
  • Parking: There is some free parking on the residential streets to the north. Please be respectful and check the parking signs.

Accessibility:

  • Davisville station is wheelchair accessible.
  • It's a fairly level roll to the park.
  • Oriel park has large accessible washrooms.
  • WheelTrans - multiple spots for drop off.

Connect With TorontoJS

  • Find us online: https://torontojs.com
  • Join us on Slack!
  • You can also find TorontoJS events on Guild.host: https://guild.host/torontojs/events

***

title: TorontoJS PubScript Social at The Firkin on Yonge!

dateTime.displayText: Friday, August 2, 20246:30 PM to 10:30 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

We're BACK! Your favourite TorontoJS social event at at pub is being resurrected after the pandemic. And the best part is, it will more inclusive and wheelchair accessible this time. Current, past, and new members welcome, as are drinkers and non-drinkers!

Friends + Code + Pub = FUN!

TorontoJS PubScript event is a fun relaxed event where like-minded individuals get together, have a snack, meal, or drink, network, and talk JavaScript and software development.

Ping pong / table tennis table will be available for the first event, and there are dart boards located at the back of the second floor.

Everyone is welcome to join us. If you are coming for the first time, don't be shy! This is a relaxed social event. It's totally fine if you need to arrive late or leave early.

Attendees can also register on TorontoJS's page on Guild: https://guild.host/torontojs/events

Location
The Firkin on Yonge is on the east side of Yonge Street, just north of Queen Street and across from the Eaton Centre.
Firkin on Yonge
207 Yonge St
Toronto, Ontario
M5B 2H1
Google Maps link

Menu
View the menu online.
Traditional English and North American pub food is available, as are alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks options.

Notes:

  • The TorontoJS Code of Conduct applies. Be nice! Read the code of conduct online.
  • Please make sure to be respectful to staff and tip well!
  • The Firkin isn't charging TorontoJS a booking fee for the PubScript series of socials or other social events.
  • We're thrilled to have a free venue for regular social events and want to keep a positive relationship with the Firkin!
  • We have members, volunteers, and future guests who use mobility aids (walking canes, wheelchairs, and service dogs) - including ones organizing our social events.
  • Under no circumstances should anyone ever touch a mobility aid (e.g. mobility cane, crutches, or wheelchair) or distract a service dog! Treat mobility aids as extensions of a person - even when the person isn't currently using their mobility aid. If you need a mobility aid moved, ask the person it belongs to.

### Transit:

  • TTC: Right near Queen TTC Station, and on the Yonge bus line
  • GO Transit: Two stops north of Union Station on the Yonge subway line

### Cycling:

  • Close to the Richmond and Adelaide east/west cycle tracks
  • There's Bike Share Toronto docking stations nearby. The closest is on Richmond Street at Yonge.

### Driving:

  • Check with Green P for public parking lots. With the Firkin on Yonge being in the heart of downtown Toronto there's parking, but it's much easier to take transit.

## Accessibility Notes:

### Venue

The Firkin is wheelchair accessible with level access, elevator to the second floor and to the washrooms in the basement. Washrooms are accessible with accessible stalls in each gendered washroom. The Firkin hosts events by A11yTO, so the staff handles disability accommodation requests professionally and respectfully.

### Transit

Queen Station is wheelchair accessible. The accessible exit from the nothbound platform is just a half block south from The Firkin. Go straight ahead when you exit at the street. The door is pointing in the correct direction (north/right).

WheelTrans can drop off on Yonge. The Firkin entrance is right near the stairway TTC entrance on the sidewalk.

If you need accessibility accommodations, please reply to this form: https://forms.gle/FqQf6w8csEJjehiF7

***Please contact the organizers if you have any accessibility questions or concerns.***

title: Code Club: Mid-summer

dateTime.displayText: Saturday, July 20, 20244:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

It is not a Scandinavian horror film, but we hope the event will be thrilling!
Join us for a cool two hours of mob programming where we can work on all kinds of code, even though it is not The Purge! (The TorontoJS Code of Conduct still applies)

About Code Club

TorontoJS Code Club is a friendly coding environment where we can bounce ideas & ask questions freely while working on software challenges together.
Please bring your projects/ideas to the event, or just show up and contribute to the discussion!

  • We can tackle an open-source issue together. Some issues don't require much context to solve and are suitable for beginners too. This group programming event can be a great opportunity to start your open-source journey.
  • We can hack on personal projects together. Is there a bug in your software that you want to fix with the group? Is there a feature you want to add? How about some refactoring to clean up your codebase? It's fun to see how everyone has different approaches to solve these technical challenges.
  • Are you job searching? We can take a look at Leetcode-style interview questions together.
  • Countless new libraries appear in the JS ecosystem every year. We can try out a new piece of tech together and share our first impressions.

This event is not about competition or achievements. Come for the pure joy of building. Everyone is welcome!

Platform

The event will be hosted on the TorontoJS discord server, on the #js-code-club channel.

Accessibility Accommodations

This is an online event on Discord, please feel free to contact us at [events@torontojs.com](mailto:events@torontojs.com) if you need any accommodations for the event.
Our Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events.

title: New Volunteer Information and Orientation Online Meeting!

dateTime.displayText: Tuesday, July 16, 20247:00 AM to 7:50 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

Do you want to be part of an awesome community that's one of the largest tech meetups in the world, while gaining career experience, building a portfolio, and developing your leadership skills and professional portfolio?

TorontoJS is recruiting volunteers for in-person, hybrid, and remote positions!

Did you know that our members and volunteers are not just in Toronto, and that we're not just JavaScript! We welcome people from any field in tech and with any level of skills - from students and those considering a career change up to seasoned professionals with decades of experience.

TorontoJS is dedicated to providing a welcoming, safe, inclusive and supportive environment for all regardless of their gender, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, or religion.
Please read the code of conduct prior to attending this meeting. https://torontojs.com/code_of_conduct

We're growing!
There's four new teams with a wide range of programs and various levels of volunteer roles:

  1. Volunteer Management Team
  2. Accessibility Team
  3. Design Team
  4. Women in Tech

We also need events volunteers for both in-person and online events.

Commitment for roles ranges from one evening a month and/or half an hour a week, through to leadership positions with long-term commitments.
All volunteers will be invited to attend volunteer only special events including the new "May the Fourth annual volunteer party"!

This is a meeting for new and existing volunteers interested in positions for:

  • The new Design Team,
  • Volunteer management team,
  • Accessibility team, and
  • Women in Tech team (leadership)
  • In-person and online Events,

This meeting will cover:

  • History and info about TorontoJS
  • About how TorontoJS is growing.
  • The new Volunteer Management Software (VMS) development project.
  • Current and future volunteer positions
  • Timelines
  • Expectations
  • Volunteer benefits
  • how these positions will help TorontoJS members and volunteers
  • Q&A

Connect With TorontoJS

  • Website: https://torontojs.com
  • Join us on Slack!
  • Follow us on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/torontojs/
  • You can also find TorontoJS events on Guild.host: https://guild.host/torontojs/events

Everyone is welcome to join us. If you are coming for the first time, don't be shy! This is a relaxed social event. It's totally fine if you need to arrive late or leave early.

Attendees can also register on TorontoJS's page on Guild: https://guild.host/torontojs/events

Location
The Firkin on Yonge is on the east side of Yonge Street, just north of Queen Street and across from the Eaton Centre.
Firkin on Yonge
207 Yonge St
Toronto, Ontario
M5B 2H1
Google Maps link

Menu
View the menu online.
Traditional English and North American pub food is available, as are alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks options.

Notes:

  • The TorontoJS Code of Conduct applies. Be nice! Read the code of conduct online.
  • Please make sure to be respectful to staff and tip well!
  • The Firkin isn't charging TorontoJS a booking fee for the PubScript series of socials or other social events.
  • We're thrilled to have a free venue for regular social events and want to keep a positive relationship with the Firkin!
  • We have members, volunteers, and future guests who use mobility aids (walking canes, wheelchairs, and service dogs) - including ones organizing our social events.
  • Under no circumstances should anyone ever touch a mobility aid (e.g. mobility cane, crutches, or wheelchair) or distract a service dog! Treat mobility aids as extensions of a person - even when the person isn't currently using their mobility aid. If you need a mobility aid moved, ask the person it belongs to.

### Transit:

  • TTC: Right near Queen TTC Station, and on the Yonge bus line
  • GO Transit: Two stops north of Union Station on the Yonge subway line

### Cycling:

  • Close to the Richmond and Adelaide east/west cycle tracks
  • There's Bike Share Toronto docking stations nearby. The closest is on Richmond Street at Yonge.

### Driving:

  • Check with Green P for public parking lots. With the Firkin on Yonge being in the heart of downtown Toronto there's parking, but it's much easier to take transit.

## Accessibility Notes:

### Venue

The Firkin is wheelchair accessible with level access, elevator to the second floor and to the washrooms in the basement. Washrooms are accessible with accessible stalls in each gendered washroom. The Firkin hosts events by A11yTO, so the staff handles disability accommodation requests professionally and respectfully.

### Transit

The closest accessible station is usually Queen Station, but due to water damage the northbound platform station is not accessible until July, 2024. If you are arriving from Union or if you are going home north bound you will need an alternate route.

The closest accessible TTC routes are:

  1. Yonge bus north to Dundas Station or Wellesley Station
  2. St. Andrew Station, then the King Street streetcar east to Yonge Street. Walk or roll north three blocks. The streetcar tracks on the east side of Queen are filled in so it's an easy wheel over them (no front casters getting stuck)!
  3. Union, then the Bay bus north. Catch the bus at the SE corner of Bay and Front Streets. Get off at Queen and Bay. Walk or roll east one block. (Note there is construction so it's quite a tight sidewalk with bumps.)

WheelTrans can drop off on Yonge. The Firkin entrance is right near the stairway TTC entrance on the sidewalk.

If you need accessibility accommodations or prefer to register via an online form, please reply to this form: https://forms.gle/FqQf6w8csEJjehiF7

***Please contact the organizers if you have any accessibility questions or concerns.***

title: JS Tech Talk [ONLINE] Things I wish I knew for my first software job

dateTime.displayText: Friday, June 28, 20247:00 AM to 8:30 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

üôå TorontoJS Tech Talks are Back Online! again! What I wish I knew for my first software job!
We're thrilled to announce the return of TorontoJS Tech Talks to the virtual stage! This session, we're diving into the topic of what we wished we'd known for our first software job!

üëã Meet Our Special Guest,
Abdul grew up in Toronto and currently lives in Taiwan. He loves to travel, learn about new technologies, and is passionate about the web and teaching. He started programming with Free Code Camp & CS50 and he‚Äôs been tinkering since. Abdul has experience working as a front-end software engineer in a startup environment and in leadership roles as a teacher. He enjoys learning about software architecture, spending time customizing his editor (vim), and the occasional leet code-ing.
Lastly, Abdul is excited to teach and help others who are entering the field by sharing some of the lessons that his experience and mentors have imparted to him.

title: TorontoJS is a proud partner of Sanity Community Meetup

dateTime.displayText: Monday, June 24, 20245:00 PM to 7:00 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

TorontoJS is a proud sponsor of the Sanity Community Meetup to meet the team, learn, and hang out with folks building with Sanity in Toronto.
We'll make sure you aren't hungry or thirsty at the event.
786 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1N6
Agenda

Powering a Sports Media Company with Sanity (Sam Mason, The GIST)

The GIST is a fan-first sports media brand that's shaking up the male-dominated sports industry by providing equal coverage to women's and men's sports. Sam joins us to tell us how they use Sanity for everything from powering a million-subscriber email newsletter to podcast integrations and custom inputs.

What's new with Sanity? (Knut Melv√¶r, Sanity)
Knut on everything new to the Sanity platform you might have missed and some soon-to-come sneak peeks on upcoming features!
More talks to be announced soon!

Call for presentations

We're looking for speakers who want to share their stories working with Sanity. If you want to propose a talk, send an email to [knut@sanity.io](mailto:knut@sanity.io) with some notes on the following:

  • What was the goal of your project?
  • How did it go?
  • What did you learn?

We usually look for a talk to be about 20 minutes.
Register for the event here:
https://lu.ma/sanity-community-meetup-toronto-june2024

title: TorontoJS PubScript Social at The Firkin on Yonge!

dateTime.displayText: Friday, June 7, 20246:30 PM to 10:30 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

We're BACK! Your favourite TorontoJS social event at at pub is being resurrected after the pandemic. And the best part is, it will more inclusive and wheelchair accessible this time. Current, past, and new members welcome, as are drinkers and non-drinkers!

Friends + Code + Pub = FUN!

TorontoJS PubScript event is a fun relaxed event where like-minded individuals get together, have a snack, meal, or drink, network, and talk JavaScript and software development.

Ping pong / table tennis table will be available for the first event, and there are dart boards located at the back of the second floor.
Everyone is welcome to join us. If you are coming for the first time, don't be shy!

This is a relaxed social event. It's totally fine if you need to arrive late or leave early.

Due to accessibility issues on Guild.host we're opening up registrations here on Meetup.
Attendees can also register on Guild https://guild.host/events/torontojs-pubscript-4q67tb to reserve their spot

Location
The Firkin on Yonge is on the east side of Yonge Street, just north of Queen Street and across from the Eaton Centre.
Firkin on Yonge
207 Yonge St
Toronto, Ontario
M5B 2H1
Google Maps link

Menu
View the menu online.
Traditional English and North American pub food is available, as are alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks options.

Notes:

  • The TorontoJS Code of Conduct applies. Be nice! Read the code of conduct online.
  • Please make sure to be respectful to staff and tip well!
  • The Firkin isn't charging TorontoJS a booking fee for the PubScript series of socials or other social events.
  • We're thrilled to have a free venue for regular social events and want to keep a positive relationship with the Firkin!
  • We have members, volunteers, and future guests who use mobility aids (walking canes, wheelchairs, and service dogs) - including ones organizing our social events.
  • Under no circumstances should anyone ever touch a mobility aid (e.g. mobility cane, crutches, or wheelchair) or distract a service dog! Treat mobility aids as extensions of a person - even when the person isn't currently using their mobility aid. If you need a mobility aid moved, ask the person it belongs to.

### Transit:

  • TTC: Right near Queen TTC Station, and on the Yonge bus line
  • GO Transit: Two stops north of Union Station on the Yonge subway line

### Cycling:

  • Close to the Richmond and Adelaide east/west cycle tracks
  • There's Bike Share Toronto docking stations nearby. The closest is on Richmond Street at Yonge.

### Driving:

  • Check with Green P for public parking lots. With the Firkin on Yonge being in the heart of downtown Toronto there's parking, but it's much easier to take transit.

## Accessibility Notes:

### Venue

The Firkin is wheelchair accessible with level access, elevator to the second floor and to the washrooms in the basement. Washrooms are accessible with accessible stalls in each gendered washroom. The Firkin hosts events by A11yTO, so the staff handles disability accommodation requests professionally and respectfully.

### Transit

The closest accessible station is Queen Station. There is currently (Monday, June 3rd) one elevator out of service at Queen Station. Exiting via southbound and northbound is working (we've tested). For Southbound use Eaton Centre concourse to street.

Please call the Lift Line Service before you travel. 416-539-LIFT (5438).

The closest accessible TTC routes are:

  1. Yonge bus north to Dundas Station or Wellesley Station
  2. St. Andrew Station, then the King Street streetcar east to Yonge Street. Walk or roll north three blocks. The streetcar tracks on the east side of Queen are filled in so it's an easy wheel over them (no front casters getting stuck)!
  3. Union, then the Bay bus north. Catch the bus at the SE corner of Bay and Front Streets. Get off at Queen and Bay. Walk or roll east one block. (Note there is construction so it's quite a tight sidewalk with bumps.)

WheelTrans can drop off on Yonge. The Firkin entrance is right near the stairway TTC entrance on the sidewalk.

If you need accessibility accommodations or use assistive tech and prefer to register via Google forms, please reply to this form: https://forms.gle/FqQf6w8csEJjehiF7

***Please contact the organizers if you have any accessibility questions or concerns.***

Square graphic. Says "TorontoJS PubScript" inside a London Underground roundel sign.
White text on blue background: "Monthly Pub Socials!
6:30pm Every First Friday of the Month
The Firkin on Yonge (at Queen). 2nd floor lounge. Darts and ping pong
Near Queen Subway Station
Wheelchair accessible. TorontoJS logo with CN Tower and JS is in the bottom left corner.

title: Toronto JS Tech Talk Event [in person]

dateTime.displayText: Thursday, June 6, 20245:30 PM to 9:00 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

Welcome back folks, to another exciting Tech Talk event at Snowflake on June 6th! Tonight is going to be exceptional, with not one, not two, but three fantastic speakers lined up, each ready to do a 30-minute talk about a variety of topics. And guess what? There will be pizza and non-alcoholic drinks waiting for you too!

We are also thrilled to announce that Alex Okrushko from AngularToronto Meetup will be joining our event as one of the hosts and our MC for the evening. Make sure to mark your calendars and come out and join us for this very special event and discover what he has in store for us!

We are still finalizing the tech talks, and will update the agenda when we have more details, but here's a quick rundown of the schedule for the day:

FEATURING
"React TypeScript Patterns" by Hassan Djirdeh
https://www.linkedin.com/in/hassandjirdeh/

"TypeScript's Magic: Achieving End-to-End Type Safety Across the Full Stack" by Joe Zhou
https://www.linkedin.com/in/zhehuizhou/

"Performance Optimization in Next.js: Tips and Techniques" by Devang Sharma
https://www.linkedin.com/in/devang25/

Schedule:
5:30pm - doors "open"
6:00pm to 6:30pm - "TypeScript's Magic: Achieving End-to-End Type Safety Across the Full Stack" by Joe Zhou
6:30pm to 7:00pm - "React TypeScript Patterns" by Hassan Djirdeh
7:00pm to 7:30pm - 30mins break time
7:30pm to 8:00pm - "Performance Optimization in Next.js: Tips and Techniques" by Devang Sharma
8:00pm to 9:00pm - networking time
9:00pm - everyone goes "home"

Please RSVP to confirm your attendance. If you have your friends or teammates joining please ask them to RSVP as well.

You can also RSVP at Guild:
https://guild.host/events/js-tech-talk-in-person-x0nqk7

This event is open to all skill levels.

Many thanks to Snowflake for hosting us!

We're looking for sponsors for events like these. If you or your company would like to support TorontoJS and get a message out to our community, please get in touch with [organizers@torontojs.com](mailto:organizers@torontojs.com)
The Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events and spaces - online or in-person.

Gendered toilets and a single occupancy accessible toilet are available.
TorontoJS is a volunteer-led not-for-profit organization. Please help us with tidying up. otherwise, the venue staff and volunteers will have to pick up after you.

title: JS Tech Talk[ONLINE]: Branding for software developers - Felipe Pe√±a

dateTime.displayText: Friday, May 31, 20247:30 AM to 9:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

***

üéâ May 30th, 6:30 PM: TorontoJS Tech Talks are Back Online! again! üéâ

This Time: Branding for software developers!

We're thrilled to announce the return of TorontoJS Tech Talks to the virtual stage! This session, we're diving into the topic of personal branding as a software developer!

üëã Meet Our Special Guest:

Felipe Pe√±a is Chilean, a family man, and passionate about technology. He loves to travel, meet people, and is usually caught reading 1 or 2 books. Felipe is also a computer engineer. He started more than 15 years ago developing software and found his passion in mobile applications. He has been involved in multiple projects of various areas and technical complexity, in both startup and corporate environments. His skills range from architecture definition, team management, and product infrastructure definition. Lastly, Felipe also loves teaching and helping other people acquire skills and knowledge in the areas of leadership, career discovery, and personal productivity.

Schedule:
6:30 pm - Warm welcome and introduction by TorontoJS

title: TorontoJS Code Buddy Club on Discord(online): Learning TypeScript

dateTime.displayText: Wednesday, May 22, 20247:30 AM to 8:30 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

## What is a Code Buddy Club

  • It's similar to a book club but uses free courses and tutorials instead of books
  • Participants are free to code independently, or to pair program.
  • Meet on discord to share progress, provide support, and help with debugging
  • Each course should take roughly 1 - 8 weeks to complete
  • It's a really relaxed, supportive, and social atmosphere.

## 2024 Courses List and Schedule

### Regular meetings

  • Sundays 11am-12pm
  • Tuesdays 6:30pm-7:30pm
  • Location: TorontoJS Discord on the Code Buddy Channel https://discord.com/channels/1078763949132107926/1183920018799472784
  • ** Contact us on Slack if you need a Discord Invite! https://join.slack.com/t/torontojs/shared_invite/zt-zgi31snl-omO3tXSZ0Q7zqN9WBQSf8Q

Course

title: Code Club: May the source be with you!

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, May 19, 20245:00 AM to 7:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

"Help me coding-one, you are my only hope!" - Princess LLaMA

If you need help or just passing by to sense the force, come and join this group of awesome Jedis!

TorontoJS Code Club is a friendly coding environment where we can bounce ideas & ask questions freely while working on software challenges together.

Please bring your projects/ideas to the event, or just show up and contribute to the discussion!

  • We can tackle an open-source issue together. Some issues don't require much context to solve and are suitable for beginners too. This group programming event can be a great opportunity to start your open-source journey.
  • We can hack on personal projects together. Is there a bug in your software that you want to fix with the group? Is there a feature you want to add? How about some refactoring to clean up your codebase? It's fun to see how everyone has different approaches to solve these technical challenges.
  • Are you job searching? We can take a look at Leetcode-style interview questions together.
  • Countless new libraries appear in the JS ecosystem every year. We can try out a new piece of tech together and share our first impressions.

This event is not about competition or achievements. Come for the pure joy of building.

Our Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events.

title: Toronto JS Lightning Talk Event [in person]

dateTime.displayText: Tuesday, April 30, 20246:00 PM to 9:00 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

# Toronto Js Lightning Talk Event

After a three year hiatus, we‚Äôre back with another Lightning Talk event at Super.com! üëã! Tonight we‚Äôll feature 10 speakers, each doing a 10-15 minute talk about a variety of topics. Also, there‚Äôs pizza!

This event is open to all skill levels.

FEAURING
"Develop Web Applications with Modern Angular" by Dale Nguyen
https://www.linkedin.com/in/dalenguyenblogger/

"The web can do that?!" By Marco Campos
https://www.linkedin.com/in/madcampos/

"Dating in different timezones" by Danny Kim
https://www.linkedin.com/in/0916dhkim/

"Open API in all its swagger" by Yuri Yang
https://www.linkedin.com/in/07yuri/

"How JS applications are built and deployed at Stripe" by Michael Humiston
https://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelhumiston/

"Accessibility isn‚Äôt just for users: Creating engaging technical presentations with accessibility in mind‚Äù by Elizabeth McCready
https://www.linkedin.com/in/elizabethmccready/

"My Journey of Building a Figma Widget with the Notion API‚Äù by Suhyeong Lee
https://www.linkedin.com/in/suhyeong-evan-lee/

"Stop narrowing the browser window: improve testing for responsiveness‚Äù by Jen Chan
https://www.linkedin.com/in/jennifer7chan/

"Deploy your own LLM, local or on-cloud‚Äù by Hardik Raj Hajela
https://www.linkedin.com/in/hardik-hajela/

"Why would you write a library? The value of building things from scratch" by Kaung Zin Hein
https://www.linkedin.com/in/kaung-zin-hein-4284a2258/

Stay tuned for more speakers and topics!
Your hosts, Sami, Aman & Evert

## Schedule:

6:00 PM - doors "open"
6:30 PM - Lightning Talks begin
8:30 PM - Networking time
9:00 PM - everyone goes "home"
(Note: All times in the schedule are an approximation.)
Many thanks to Super.com for hosting us!

We're looking for sponsors for events like these. If you or your company would like to support TorontoJS and get a message out to our community, please get in touch with [organizers@torontojs.com](mailto:organizers@torontojs.com)

The Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events and spaces - online or in-person.

Gendered toilets and a single occupancy accessible toilet are available.
TorontoJS is a volunteer-led not-for-profit organization. Please help us with tidying up; otherwise, the venue staff and volunteers will have to pick up after you.

title: Code Club: Code Eclipse

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, April 28, 20245:00 AM to 7:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

Don't stare directly into the solar eclipse! Instead, stare at your monitor while you attend April's Code Club event! TorontoJS Code Club is a friendly coding environment where we can bounce ideas & ask questions freely while working on software challenges together. Please bring your projects/ideas to the event, or just show up and contribute to the discussion!

  • We can tackle an open-source issue together. Some issues don't require much context to solve and are suitable for beginners too. This group programming event can be a great opportunity to start your open-source journey. üöÄ

  • We can hack on personal projects together. Is there a bug in your software that you want to fix with the group? Is there a feature you want to add? How about some refactoring to clean up your codebase? It's fun to see how everyone has different approaches to solve these technical challenges. üñ•Ô∏è

  • Are you job searching? We can take a look at Leetcode-style interview questions together. üëè

  • Countless new libraries appear in the JS ecosystem every year. We can try out a new piece of tech together and share our first impressions. üëÄ

This event is not about competition or achievements. Come for the pure joy of building.

Our Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events.

title: TorontoJS Tech Talk [Online] - April 25th, 2024 (Apr 25, 2024)

dateTime.displayText: Friday, April 26, 20247:00 AM to 9:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

***

üéâ TorontoJS Tech Talks are Back Online! üéâ

This Time: Exploring Cognitive Accessibility

Join us for the exciting return of TorontoJS Tech Talks, now in a virtual format! This session, we're delving into "The Current State of Cognitive Accessibility," a crucial topic for tech enthusiasts, developers, and anyone interested in creating more accessible and inclusive technology. Get ready for an evening of engaging discussions, learning, and networking, all from the comfort of your home.

üëã Meet Our Special Guest, Shruti Vellanki

Shruti will lead a discussion on "The Current State of Cognitive Accessibility," exploring its various aspects and the comprehensive guidelines established by organizations such as the W3C's COGA and Finnish Guidelines. She'll also address the challenges inherent in making technology universally accessible due to the complexity of cognitive accessibility.

About Shruti Vellanki:
Shruti is a dedicated Software Engineer with a passion for Front-End Development, Design Systems, Component Libraries, and Accessibility. She's also an avid reader of nonfiction and an active participant in the Toronto Public Library's Culture and Technology Bookclub. Shruti's presentation promises to offer valuable insights and practical strategies for enhancing cognitive accessibility in technology.

Event Schedule:

  • 6:00 pm- Warm welcome and introduction by TorontoJS
    6:10 pm - Presentation by Shruti Vellanki
    6:40 pm - Interactive Q&A Session
    7:00 pm - Networking Opportunity
    7:20 PM - Closing Remarks

‚≠ê Don't miss this opportunity to deepen your understanding of cognitive accessibility and its impact on technology development. This event will take place on Zoom, bringing together participants from around the world in an inspiring virtual setting.

Interested in speaking or sponsoring? Reach out to us at organizers@torontojs.com.
TorontoJS is committed to fostering a safe and inclusive environment for everyone, both online and at our events and spaces.
We look forward to seeing you there! üöÄ

Code of Conduct is enforced online or in person at all TorontoJS events and spaces

We are always seeking sponsors and speakers for events similar to this one. If you or your company are interested in supporting TorontoJS or reaching our community, please contact organizers@torontojs.com.

detailsHtml:
Details

## Important Update for Sunday's Code Buddy Club

To all those interested in joining this week's Sunday Code Buddy Club discussion on the "Build a Modern User Interface with Chakra UI" course, we have an important update.

Considering it's a long weekend, and we think it would be a great time for everyone to take a break, enjoy the good weather outside, and spend time with loved ones, we have decided to reschedule Sunday's Code Buddy Club session to the following Tuesday. We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause and appreciate your understanding and flexibility.

Instead of the usual Code Buddy Club session, it will be an hour where we'll be chilling and talking about random stuff, essentially a fun one-hour social time with fellow developers.

I hope everyone has a wonderful and lovely long weekend. See you all soon!

title: TorontoJS Tech Talk [Online] - March 30th, 2024 (Mar 30, 2024)

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, March 31, 20244:00 AM to 5:25 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

TorontoJS Tech Talk [Online] welcomes you to an electrifying virtual gathering where tech enthusiasts unite! Prepare for an immersive experience focused on cutting-edge tech talks, insightful discussions, and vibrant connections. Our highlight? A captivating presentation led by our esteemed guest host. Join us as they lead the way through an evening of curiosity, collaboration, and a deep dive into the world of JavaScript and beyond.

üëã Special Guest: John Page Topic: "The truth behind MongoDB they don't want you to know"

A veteran of the database industry, John joined MongoDB over 10 years ago, having spent the previous 18 years working on proprietary NoSQL document databases and search technologies for the Intelligence community. He has been a Software Engineer, Presales Architect, and Professional Services Consultant and now works in Developer Advocacy. John considers himself a full-stack engineer, having written everything from operating systems to training courses and every level in-between. Nowadays, John, a maker at heart, builds hardware and software blending MongoDB with other technologies from tiny microcontrollers to infinitely scalable cloud services to solve problems - MongoDB pays him to write and talk about them. He lives in the Scottish countryside with three Labradors, four squirrels, and various robots.

üöÄ Agenda:

  • 3:00 PM - Introduction & welcome notes from TorontoJS
  • 3:10 PM - John Page's Tech Talk on MongoDB
  • 3:40 PM - Q&A Session and/or Mob Programming
  • 4:00 PM - Networking
  • 4:20 PM - Closing Remarks

üìß Contact: organizers@torontojs.com

Elevate your tech journey with us! Be part of an engaging experience where passion for code meets the thrill of learning. See you there!

Code of Conduct is enforced online or in person at all TorontoJS events and spaces

We are always seeking sponsors and speakers for events similar to this one. If you or your company are interested in supporting TorontoJS or reaching our community, please contact organizers@torontojs.com.

title: JS Tech Talk [In-Person]  CSS-Edit | Streaming & Coding Contests [RSVP on Guild]

dateTime.displayText: Wednesday, March 27, 20246:00 PM to 9:00 PM EDT

detailsHtml:
Details

# Spring Revival: Welcoming You Back to Our Energizing March Meetup!

We would love to welcome you to our March 2024 In-Person Tech Talk Meetup at Super.com! üëã

Come out and join us for a special event with our members who are coming together to share their knowledge with the community.
We are still finalizing the tech talks, and will update the agenda when we have more details, but here's a quick rundown of the schedule for the day:

## Schedule:

6:00 pm - Doors Open
6:20 pm - Welcome notes from TorontoJS
6:30 pm - Welcome from our hosts - Super.com
6:35 pm - Beyond Text Editing with CSS-Edit - by Marcelle Rusu

Marcelle has spent the last 2 months working full-time on a from-scratch structural editor for css.

They are going to talk about the experience of having the freedom/pressure of working on DX full-time, the current state and dreams for the future

About Marcelle: "Marcelle Rusu (they/them) is a solo developer deeply passionate about client-side programming, language design, and DX tooling. They have done front-end work for about 5-6 years ranging from react, svelte, and even elm. "

7:15 pm - Web video streaming and the rise of coding competitions - by Daniel Stoianov

Daniel is going to talk about his experience participating in a Contest for developers for implementing live streaming browsing feature. He will talk a little about which technologies for web streaming are most popular right now and will try to to combine them with his solution.

About Daniel: "Daniel has been in development professionally since 2017, he remembers the era when jQuery was a prominent tool and even recalls some flash elements in the browser. Not only does he enjoy being a frontend developer, but he also finds pleasure in exploring other fields within development. He particularly likes experimenting with backend technologies and indulging in pet projects related to video."

8:00 pm - Networking
9:00 pm - Doors Close
(Note: All times in the schedule are an approximation.)
Many thanks to Super.com for hosting us!

We're looking for sponsors for events like these. If you or your company would like to support TorontoJS and get a message out to our community, please get in touch with [organizers@torontojs.com](mailto:organizers@torontojs.com)

The Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events and spaces - online or in-person.

Gendered toilets and a single occupancy accessible toilet are available.
TorontoJS is a volunteer-led not-for-profit organization. Please help us with tidying up; otherwise, the venue staff and volunteers will have to pick up after you.

IMPORTANT: Attendees must RSVP on Guild: JS Tech Talk [In-Person] - CSS-Edit: Beyond Text Editing | Streaming & Coding Contests: A Digital Surge | Guild

title: Code Club [Online]: RFCs and proposals

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, March 24, 20245:00 AM to 7:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

Join us for an exciting TorontoJS meetup where we'll explore the new proposal process for Toronto JS and collaborate on the Toronto JS blog project in the main room. This event welcomes all, so come and contribute your ideas! üöÄ

Additionally, feel free to bring your projects to work on in other rooms. TorontoJS Code Club provides a welcoming coding environment where you can freely brainstorm ideas, seek advice, and tackle software challenges together. üí°

Whether you have a specific project in mind or simply want to join the discussion, this event is for you. It's a fantastic opportunity to collaborate on beginner-friendly open-source issues, receive feedback on and work on personal projects, address bugs, implement new features, or enhance your codebase, explore Leetcode-style interview questions for those in job search, and experiment with and share insights on new JS libraries. üõ†Ô∏è

title: JS Tech Talk[Online]: Hussien Khayoon React Testing

dateTime.displayText: Friday, March 1, 20248:30 AM to 10:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

üôå TorontoJS tech talks are now online!

TorontoJS Tech Talk [Online] welcomes you to an electrifying virtual gathering where tech enthusiasts unite! Prepare for an immersive experience focused on cutting-edge tech talks, insightful discussions, and vibrant connections. Our highlight? A captivating presentation led by our esteemed guest host. Join us as they lead the way through an evening of curiosity, collaboration, and a deep dive into the world of JavaScript and beyond. Elevate your tech journey with us, and be part of an engaging experience where passion for code meets the thrill of learning.

üëã Come out and join us with special guest Hussien Khayoon who will lead a talk on React Testing.

Hussien is a Staff Developer at Shopify. He has over 12 years of full-stack experience with a particular soft spot for React. He also mentors for a coding boot camp and loves helping beginners break into tech.

Hussien will be talking about testing with React to build high-quality software.

Schedule:

6:30 pm - Introduction & welcome notes from TorontoJS
6:40 pm - Hussien Khayoon
7:10 pm - Question Period and or mob programming
7:25 pm - Networking
7:40 PM - Final words

We look forward to seeing you!

The event will be held on zoom.

We're always looking for speakers and sponsors for our events. Reach to us @ [organizers@torontojs.com](mailto:organizers@torontojs.com)

Learn more about all our events

Code of Conduct is enforced online or in person at all TorontoJS events and spaces.

title: JS Tech Talk [In-Person] - Filesystems, and QwikJS

dateTime.displayText: Tuesday, February 27, 20246:00 PM to 9:00 PM EST

detailsHtml:
Details

üôå Welcome back to our first meetup of 2024!

We welcome you to our February 2024 In-Person Tech Talk Meetup at Super.com! üëã

Come out and join us for a special event with our members who are coming together to share their knowledge with the community.

NOTE: RSVP on our Guild page: https://guild.host/events/js-tech-talk-inperson-z5zmjq

Schedule:
6:00 pm - Doors Open

6:20 pm - Welcome notes from TorontoJS

6:30 pm - Welcome from our hosts - Super.com

6:35 pm - Introduction to QwikJS : build blazing fast web apps at the Edge - by Brandon Cha
About Brandon: "Brandon Cha (he/him) is a Software Developer who loves exploring different cultures through food, travel, and experiences. He previously worked in development as a B2B and B2C solutions consultant primarily within the media and entertainment industry, he likes to discover and find creative solutions to solve the next challenge in web and application development from frontend to the backend. In this talk, Brandon will be sharing with us how the QwikJS framework is easy to use and setup, and why its envious Edge-optimized loading time shows us a glimpse of the future in how frontend development is built and deployed."

7:05 pm - Introductions to File Systems - by Evert Pot
About Evert: "Evert Pot has been building web applications for 20 years and is currently CTO at Sprout Family. Check out his blog: https://evertpot.com"

7:35 pm - Networking

9:00 pm - Doors Close

(Note: All times in the schedule are an approximation.)

Many thanks to Super.com for hosting us!

He previously worked in development as a B2B and B2C solutions consultant primarily within the media and entertainment industry, he likes to discover and find creative solutions to solve the next challenge in web and application development from frontend to the backend. In this talk, Brandon will be sharing with us how the QwikJS framework is easy to use and setup, and why its envious Edge-optimized loading time shows us a glimpse of the future in how frontend development is built and deployed."
7:05 pm - Introductions to File Systems - by Evert Pot
About Evert: "Evert Pot has been building web applications for 20 years and is currently CTO at Sprout Family. Check out his blog: https://evertpot.com"
7:35 pm - Networking
9:00 pm - Doors Close
(Note: All times in the schedule are an approximation.)
Many thanks to Super.com for hosting us!

detailsHtml:

## What is a Code Buddy Club

  • It's similar to a book club but uses free courses and tutorials instead of books
  • Participants are free to code independently, or to pair program.
  • Meet on discord to share progress, provide support, and help with debugging
  • Each course should take roughly 1 - 8 weeks to complete
  • It's a really relaxed, supportive, and social atmosphere.

title: JS Code Club [Online] - February 2024

dateTime.displayText: Sunday, February 25, 20246:00 AM to 8:00 AM JST

detailsHtml:
Details

After taking a break for a couple of months, Code Club is back for its first event of the year!

TorontoJS Code Club is a friendly coding environment where we can bounce ideas & ask questions freely while working on software challenges together.

Please bring your projects/ideas to the event, or just show up and contribute to the discussion!

We can tackle an open-source issue together. Some issues don't require much context to solve and are suitable for beginners too. This group programming event can be a great opportunity to start your open-source journey.

Are you job searching? We can take a look at Leetcode-style interview questions together.

Countless new libraries appear in the JS ecosystem every year. We can try out a new piece of tech together and share our first impressions.

This event is not about competition or achievements. Come for the pure joy of building.

The event will be held on the TorontoJS discord.

The TorontoJS Code of Conduct is enforced at all TorontoJS events.

Find out more information about events @ Guild
